clinical_validity.disease_label: myopathy caused by variation in FKRP
clinical_validity.gcep: Muscular Dystrophies and Myopathies Gene Curation Expert Panel

generif.text: Limb girdle muscular dystrophy 2I is a milder allelic variant of MDC1C.

FKRP mutations can result in muscular dystrophy with mental retardation & cerebellar cysts, adding structural brain defects to the FKRP mutation spectrum. Depletion of alpha-dystroglycan expression suggests FKRP involvement in its processing.
patients with mutations in the fukutin-related protein (FKPR) gene had congenital muscular dystrophy
particular FKRP mutations in the homozygous state induce structural and clinical neurological lesions in addition to muscular dystrophy

Data suggest that fukutin and fukutin-related protein (FKRP) may be involved at different steps in O-mannosylglycan synthesis of alpha-dystroglycan, and FKRP is most likely involved in the initial step in this synthesis.
pathogenesis of congenital muscular dystrophies, severity is related to ability to transport protein to ER
a type of LGMD in the Hutterite population maps to chromosome 19q31-q33 and is due to homozygosity for the L276I mutation in FKRP.
Three siblings without clinical signs of muscle dystrophy, but with dilated cardiomyopathy have C826A Fukutin-related protein mutation.

A FKRP point mutation, L276I has been found in all patients with LGMD2I studied so far. The authors screened for this mutation in 102 sporadic cases of Duchenne/Becker mutation-negative patients and found 13 patients with LGMD2I.

Retention in the endoplasmic reticulum of FKRP is not the main mechanism of disease; this may instead relate to a disruption of the functional activity of this putative enzyme with its substrate(s) in the Golgi.
FKRP mutations are a frequent cause of limb-girdle muscular dystrophies. The degree of respiratory and cardiac insufficiency in patients did not correlate with the severity of muscle involvement.
A novel FKRP gene((c.823C>T (p.R275C) and c.948delC)mutation in a Taiwanese patient with limb-girdle muscular dystrophy 2I

We report a limb-girdle muscular dystrophy 2I family with three affected sisters and a highly variable clinical course. FKRP gene sequencing showed that all three sisters carried a nonsense paternal mutation (W225X).
two unrelated Mexican children with congenital muscular dystrophy who each have the identical, novel 1387A>G, N463D mutation.
3 new FKRP mutations were identified: L322V, L489R and R275G.
Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy (LGMD) type 2I, caused by mutations in the fukutin-related protein gene (FKRP).
The unfolded protein response is activated in LGMD2I muscle biopsies in limb girdle muscular dystrophy type 2I.
severe dilated cardiomyopathy requiring heart transplantation in a homozygous p.Leu276Ile mutation in Fukutin-related protein gene (FKRP)
findings detected a homozygous mutation of the FKRP gene (826C>A) in two unrelated patients with limb-girdle muscular dystrophy 2I with necrotic myopathy with numerous rimmed vacuoles

In our population of LGMD2I patients, different mutations in the FKRP gene are associated with several secondary muscle protein reductions, and the deficiencies of alpha2-laminin and alpha-DG on sections are prevalent.
Data show that four sibs belonging to a second Tunisian LGMD2I family show variable cardiac involvement with FKRP gene mutations.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
our study confirms that typical clinical symptoms (calf hypertrophy, cardiac involvement, mild LGMD) of LGMD2I due the homozygous c.826C[A mutation, are rather frequent in Germany
Alteration of the secretion pathway by different mutations may contribute to wide variations in phenotypes associated with FKRP-related diseases such as muscular dystrophy.
mutation spectrum associted with limb-girdle muscular dystrophy variability and serverity
Co-injection of fish or human FKRP mRNA along with the morpholino restored normal development and alpha-dystroglycan glycosylation.

two siblings carrying a homozygous mutation in the start codon of FKRP that is likely to result in a loss of functional FKRP protein. The clinical phenotype of the patients was consistent with Walker-Warburg syndrome
This study identified FKRP mutations on both alleles in 88 patients from 69 families with Limb Girdle Muscular Dystrophy Type 2I.
Study revealed a large homozygous block at the LGMD2I locus, and direct sequencing of FKRP encoding fukutin-related-protein detected the common homozygous c.826 C>A (p.Leu276Ile) mutation.
Two novel heterozygous mutations (c.208T>A and c.1030G>T) in the FKRP gene were identified in Chinese brothers with progressive shoulder and pelvic muscle weakness
Mutations in FKRP lead to a glycosylation defect and subsequently downregulation of alpha-dystroglycan which constitutes an essential component of the proteoglycan-dystrophin complex.
FKRP co-localises with the middle-to-trans-Golgi marker MG160, between the myofibrils in human rectus femoris muscle fibres.
This study demonistrated that the higher frequency of LGMD2I with cardiomyopathy in mutation of FKRP in Taiwanese patients.
This provide a new mouse model of Limb-Girdle Muscular Dystrophy Type 2I homozygous for the Common L276I Mutation.
Muscular dystrophies can present with rhabdomyolysis; FKRP mutations are particularly frequent in causing such complication.
Fukutin and fukutin-related protein are sequentially acting Rbo5P transferases that use cytidine diphosphate ribitol.
The 13 novel mutations of FKRP significantly expanded the mutation spectrum of MDC1C and LGMD2I, and the different founder mutations indicate the ethnic difference in FKRP mutations.
Dystrophic Pathology in Diaphragm and Impairment of Cardiac Function in FKRP P448L Mutant Mice

This study have demonstrated that the clinical heterogeneity in LGMD2I patients, homozygous for FKRP c.826C>A, cannot be explained by histopathological alterations, levels of alpha-DG hypoglycosylation or laminin alpha2 depletion.
Next generation and Sanger sequencing were performed for I-2. Heterozygous FKRP mutations were identified in exon 4: c.1167_1168delGC, p.Gly391Leufs *72 and c.501_502GT>CC, p.Arg167Ser, p.Cys168Arg
This literature review revealed that pathogenic mutations in the FKRP gene in Asian LGMD2I patients are compound heterozygous rather than homozygous.

The FKRP-related disorders should be included as a differential diagnosis in Mexican patients with neuromuscular disorders and normal results on DMD gene deletion/duplication analysis. This and previous reports, along with data from the main genotype databases, collectively suggest that in Mexico the FKRP-related disorders are due to the p.(Asn463Asp) and the common European p.(Leu276Ile) pathogenic variants.

The results suggest that fukutin and FKRP not only participate in the synthesis of O-mannosyl glycans added to alpha-dystroglycan in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi complex, but that they could also play a role, that remains to be established, in the nucleus of retinal neurons.

Fukutin, FKRP, and TMEM5 form a complex while maintaining each of their enzyme activities.  Data showed that endogenous fukutin and FKRP enzyme activities coexist with TMEM5 enzyme activity, and suggest the possibility that formation of this enzyme complex may contribute to specific and prompt biosynthesis of glycans that are required for dystroglycan function.
Muscle tissue in patients with Limb girdle muscular dystrophy type 2I who have the founder mutation c.545A>G in FKRP shows a distinctive concentric pattern of fatty infiltration and edema on MRI.
c.1303C>T mutation from FKRP came from the father and was a new missense mutation, and a bioinformatics analysis showed that it might be a pathogenic mutation

Cardiomyopathy is expected in nearly 50% of LGMD2I (LGMD-R9) patients, however we report for first time two Mexican LGMD2I siblings that died due to dilated cardiomyopathy associated to compound heterozygous genotype involving the Hispanic/Mexican pathogenic and founder FKRP allele p.[Asn463Asp] and the common European p[Leu276Ile] variant.

Fukutin and fukutin-related protein (FKRP), whose mutated genes underlie dystroglycanopathy, sequentially transfer RboP from cytidine diphosphate-ribitol (CDP-Rbo) to form a tandem RboP unit in the core M3 glycan. Crystal structures of FKRP with and without donor (CDP-Rbo) and/or acceptor [RboP-(phospho-)core M3 peptide] substrates.
Global FKRP Registry: observations in more than 300 patients with Limb Girdle Muscular Dystrophy R9.
Motor outcome measures in patients with FKRP mutations: A longitudinal follow-up.
The first report of two homozygous sequence variants in FKRP and SELENON genes associated with syndromic congenital muscular dystrophy in Iran: Further expansion of the clinical phenotypes.
Cardiomyopathy in limb girdle muscular dystrophy R9, FKRP related.
Phenotypic Spectrum of alpha-Dystroglycanopathies Associated With the c.919T>a Variant in the FKRP Gene in Humans and Mice.
Fukutin-Related Protein: From Pathology to Treatments.

[Limb-Girdle Muscular Dystrophy type R9 linked to the FKRP gene: state of the art and therapeutic perspectives].", trans "La dystrophie musculaire des ceintures de type R9 liee au gene FKRP - Etat des lieux et perspectives therapeutiques.
FKRP-dependent glycosylation of fibronectin regulates muscle pathology in muscular dystrophy.
FKRP mutations cause congenital muscular dystrophy 1C and limb-girdle muscular dystrophy 2I in Asian patients.
Defective autophagy and increased apoptosis contribute toward the pathogenesis of FKRP-associated muscular dystrophies.
Phenotype Genotype Characterization of FKRP-related Muscular Dystrophy among Indian Patients.
Insomnia and sleep-disordered breathing in FKRP-related limb-girdle muscular dystrophy R9. The Norwegian LGMDR9 cohort study (2020).
Health-Related Quality of Life in FKRP-Related Limb-Girdle Muscular Dystrophy R9.
Break Down of the Complexity and Inconsistency Between Levels of Matriglycan and Disease Phenotype in FKRP-Related Dystroglycanopathies: A Review and Model of Interpretation.

BP.term: maintenance of protein localization in endoplasmic reticulum

MF.term: phosphotransferase activity, for other substituted phosphate groups

name: fukutin related protein

kegg.name: Mannose type O-glycan biosynthesis - Homo sapiens (human)

summary: This gene encodes a protein which is targeted to the medial Golgi apparatus and is necessary for posttranslational modification of dystroglycan. Mutations in this gene have been associated with congenital muscular dystrophy, cognitive disability, and cerebellar cysts. Several alternatively spliced transcript variants of this gene have been described, but the full-length nature of some of these variants has not been determined. [provided by RefSeq, Oct 2008].
